Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Design documents are due soon and other teams are waiting for their technical input
Story: My phone buzzes for the third time in ten minutes. It’s my stepdad, asking if I’ve eaten, if I’m feeling okay, if I can call him and Mom tonight. I know they expect me to check in every day, to share how things are going, to reassure them that I’m not drifting away. But my laptop screen is filled with Slack messages from the product and QA teams, all waiting for my feedback on the new feature specs. The design document deadline is tomorrow, and everyone’s depending on my technical input to move forward. I feel the pressure mounting from both sides—my family wanting connection, my team needing collaboration. I stare at the blinking cursor in my chat window, torn between typing a message to my parents or jumping into the team call. My chest tightens as I realize I can’t give both what they want at the same time.
